questions.question_text: Which level of severity must be set to get informational syslogs?

discussion.content: Every good Cisco engineer will need intercourse daily :0

Syslog uses the User Datagram Protocol (UDP), port 514

SEVERITY LEVEL
** SEVERITY IN EVENT = Default SMS setting for Syslog Security option. 
 This setting will send all events to remote Syslog system
1 ALERT
2 CRITICAL
3 ERROR
4 WARNING
5 NOTICE
6 INFORMATIONAL (7 Debug [lower] will include ALL Informational messages)
7 DEBUG

Selected Answer: D
The level they are talking about is level6 informational but because we don't have that in our answers it can be only D . Debug- level 7.

Here's something to remember it by...
Emergencies Are Critical Even When Nobody Is Dying
Thank me by thanking yourselves

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
higher level includes the lower levels.
Every awesome Cisco engineer need icecream daily from 0-7

comments.content: Small correction: Every awesome Cisco Engineer "Will" Need Icecream Daily (Level 0-7). Don't forget "Will" i.e., Warning. :-)

discussion.content: fck this questiion

Selected Answer: D
The informational level is lower than the notice level. So only debug level can get those information. Answer D is correct.
Emma Always Cries Even When Nobody Is Dying

questions.question_text: On workstations running Microsoft Windows, which protocol provides the default gateway for the device?

discussion.content: NTP use UDP port 123.

Selected Answer: AB
A & B are correct

Selected Answer: AB
Hard to go wrong with this one.

Selected Answer: AB
A. NTP uses UDP over IP.
B. Cisco routers can act as both NTP authoritative servers and NTP clients.

choices.B: Cisco routers can act as both NTP authoritative servers and NTP clients.
choices.C: Cisco routers can act only as NTP servers.
choices.D: Cisco routers can act only as NTP clients.

questions.question_text: Which two statements about NTP operations are true? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Router1(config)#access-list 99 permit 192.168.100.32 0.0.0.31 Router1(config)#ip nat inside source list 99 interface gi1/0/0 overload Router1(config)#interface gi2/0/1.200 Router1(config)#ip nat inside Router1(config)#interface gi1/0/0 Router1(config)#ip nat outside
choices.C: Router1(config)#access-list 99 permit 209.165.201.2 255.255.255.255 Router1(config)#ip nat inside source list 99 interface gi1/0/0 overload Router1(config)#interface gi2/0/1.200 Router1(config)#ip nat inside Router1(config)#interface gi1/0/0 Router1(config)#ip nat outside
choices.D: Router1(config)#access- list 99 permit 209.165.201.2 0.0.0.0 Router1(config)#ip nat inside source list 99 interface gi1/0/0 overload Router1(config)#interface gi2/0/1.200 Router1(config)#ip nat inside Router1(config)#interface gi1/0/0 Router1(config)#ip nat outside
choices.B: Router1(config)#access-list 99 permit 192.168.100.0 0.0.0.255 Router1(config)#ip nat inside source list 99 interface gi1/0/0 overload Router1(config)#interface gi2/0/1.200 Router1(config)#ip nat inside Router1(config)#interface gi1/0/0 Router1(config)#ip nat outside

Selected Answer: AC
The default setting on switch/router to accept remote access is telnet.

Crypto key is not yet generated.

"...configuration of router R1 so that it accepts ONLY encrypted connections..."

So A + C

Selected Answer: AC

Selected Answer: AC

Selected Answer: BC
B and C must configure

comments.content: ssh1 also enforce encryption but less stronger than ssh2

discussion.content: C & E is correct

Selected Answer: AC
C & A must have RSA generated and transport input ssh

Selected Answer: AC
The ip ssh version 2 command is optional. The crypto key generate rsa 1024 is required for ssh connections. The transport input ssh command specifies that you only want to connect to the router via ssh, this way you can't connect to the router via Telnet, which doesn't support encrypted connections. Therefore, A and C.

Search for Set Up an IOS Router or Switch as SSH Client in this site:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security-vpn/secure-shell-ssh/4145-ssh.html

Selected Answer: AC
A and C

Selected Answer: AC
although “crypto key generate rsa” command enables SSH on the device, however the “transport input” command must be entered because ‘The transport command defines which protocols can be used to connect to a line. The default protocol is none, which means that no incoming connections are allowed.’

Given answer of C & E is correct. 
Given answer C & E is probably correct but A & C is good too. Go with C/E because you need C/E first (for encryption) then you do need A for remote access, so focus on “encryption” in the question. 
https://ipwithease.com/how-to-configure-ssh-version-2-on-cisco-router/

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_usr_ssh/configuration/15-s/sec-usr-ssh-15-s-book/sec-secure-shell-v2.html#:~:text=the%20default%20host.-,Configuring%20a%20Device%20for%20SSH%20Version%202%20Using%20RSA%20Key%20Pairs,-SUMMARY%20STEPS
